turn.text: Isn't it true that the patient can go to any doctor he wants to in the county?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if he goes to a non-member, he is taking the risk that he will be charged whatever the doctor wants to charge him.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And how many, what percentage of the patients do you say are covered by--

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: About 7 percent of the people in the county--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Have insurance?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --have this type of insurance in 1978, I believe.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How many of them go to doctors that are members?
Or do you know?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: I don't think we can tell from the record we have now.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I take it that the insurance... that an awful lot of doctors... a lot of patients are going to non-member doctors.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Yes, yes.
I would think so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the insurance company seems to get along all right.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Sure, because the way the foundation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because they just announce... the insurance company just has a... it just says there is a maximum that I will reimburse for, that's all.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --That's right, and the patient gets the same amount paid to the doctor whether the doctor is a foundation member or not.
There is no evidence of any effect that would coerce doctors to join the foundation, coerce patients to use foundation doctors, coerce insurers to use foundation insurance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Without any foundation at all, why couldn't the insurance companies sell policies and say, here is our schedule, we will reimburse up to a certain amount for these procedures.
If your doctor happens to charge you any more, that is too bad.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: That is exactly what happens, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: The difference in that situation is, the patient never knows in advance whether what the insurance pays will cover what the doctor bills.

If he is a member of a foundation plan, and if the doctor is a foundation doctor, then he knows in advance that whatever it costs, the foundation insurance will pay the entire bill, and he doesn't have to worry about the difference.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I don't see why this arrangement has anything to do with insurance rates.
It has got to do with whether patients have some limit to their medical bills.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: That is the benefit from the point of view of the patient, and that is why doctors who are engaged in independent practices have an incentive to join a medical foundation, because this enables them to offer something to the patient which looks to the patient like an HMO.
An HMO does the same thing in the sense that for a fixed amount of money paid for HMO, you get all the medical care that you need.
A doctor in private practice couldn't do that by himself.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any... I asked before, but I take it that it is correct that there is nothing in the record to indicate what the position of the non-member doctors in the community is with respect to this arrangement.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: The only evidence--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It must be that they haven't joined, they don't like it.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --Yes, there is evidence.
One of the affidavits points out that a number of doctors have refused to join because they feel that the maximum reimbursements are so low that they are unfair and they just can't accept them.
That is the only evidence that I am aware of in the record with respect to non-members.
We have urged that there is no showing that people are coerced to do this.
People are free to do it or not, and therefore, the market forces come into play.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, none of them have claimed that what this really is is a conspiracy among the member doctors to run them out of business by setting rates, setting low rates and getting all the patients there are in town?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Well, that is a concept that was introduced in the reply brief by the Petitioner, but it just doesn't make any sense from the economic--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There is nothing in the record about it, is there?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --That's right.
Nothing in the record.
You have to go back and get evidence in order to see whether that had anything to it or not.
What we are saying is that this foundation is structured so that market forces do come into play.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it is real strange that you say that it is perfectly obvious that this whole thing saves money, when one of the large patients, so-called, the state of Arizona, says, it doesn't save us any money at all; as a matter of fact, it costs us money.
Apparently that is what they are saying.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: No, I don't believe that is what they are saying, and we show--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why are they objecting, if you are saving them a lot of money?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --That is what I would like to know, Your Honor.
It doesn't make any sense.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't the reason, one of the reasons for their objection the feeling that if your organization were not in business, more HMOs would be in business?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: If that is their position, there is nothing in the record to support it, and it is not the basis for summary judgment.
Yes, that may well be what they ultimately intend to show.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, they certainly are... the state pays out a lot of money for insurance.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Yes.
We--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So they don't think that you are bringing them any Christmas present.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --Well, but the record does show that when the fostered chosen care plan for Arizona went from the Maricopa Foundation reimbursement schedule to a different one, the state paid more money for the same medical services.
Why did they do that?
I submit it makes no sense at all.
They did it because they thought that what Maricopa Foundation was doing was not legal, and therefore they didn't want to participate in it.
But what we would like is an opportunity to show that it is legal, it saves costs of insurance, it lowers insurance costs.
The market forces control what the maximum reimbursement rates can be.
If the rates get too high, insurers will not write Maricopa Foundation or any medical foundation insurance.
They will set their own reimbursement levels that are lower.
If the rates are too low, the doctors just won't renew their membership in the foundation.
Unless you have broad coverage, a large number of doctors participating, you don't get the attraction of a lot of physicians who will accept payment as payment in full.
So, that will cause the rates to go up.
You hit an equilibrium which according to the Link study is going to be in the neighborhood of the average or median charge in the community.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there a state antitrust law?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Yes, there is.
As a matter of fact, this action arose out of an investigation that was supposedly under the state antitrust law.
They took depositions.
They had a CRD type procedure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Put this suit wasn't based on the state antitrust law?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: There is a pendent state claim.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There is a pendent state claim.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: In the federal action, which was not the basis for the summary judgment motion which you have before you today, but it is there.
The state law is the Uniform State Antitrust Law, which is very similar to the Sherman Act.
Indeed, it says that you look at the Sherman Act precedents.

In the opposition to the summary judgment motion, the medical foundations have argued that the maximum reimbursement levels are essential to the concept and operation of medical foundation endorsed insurance.
W should be given an opportunity to produce the evidence and present it at a hearing to determine that.
The situation is very similar to the type of activity that the Court sanctioned in the Broadcast Music case.
You have the creation of a new product, different from what any individual doctor could offer by himself.
What happens is, you get full coverage insurance, which pays medical costs in full, and a peer review to avoid unnecessary procedures.
The medical foundation does put the doctor at risk, and the evidence of that is in the appendix at Page 309.
The doctor is not compensated for any additional complexity or difficulty in treatment.

If he would charge more than the maximum reimbursement level because of complexity or difficulty, it is too bad, if he is dealing with a Maricopa Foundation patient and he is a Maricopa Foundation member.
He has to write it off.
If he performs a treatment which he in good faith believes is medically necessary, and peer review of the medical foundation disagrees with him, he is at risk for that.
He has to write it off and accept their judgment.
If the costs of medical services that he must buy, if his costs of supplies and help go up because of inflation, he can't increase what he receives on the Maricopa Foundation patients.
He is locked in for a year by his membership.
And at the end of the year, he may decide not to renew, but at least for that one year he is at risk for the costs and the inflation factor.
The medical foundation reduces the transaction costs.
It enormously simplifies the negotiations between insurers and physicians.
It limits the complexity of establishing understandable maximum reimbursement levels which can be administratively handled in payments.

It lowers the cost and complexity of claim processing, and one of the functions that the medical foundations perform is the claims processing function for the insurers if the insurer desires them to do that.
All of these things make a medical foundation the same type of pro-competitive activity that the Court sanctioned in the Broadcast Music case.
It doesn't affect the prices that the individual doctors charge individually.
It only affects the prices that somebody can agree to accept by agreeing to Maricopa Foundation or Pima Foundation endorsed coverage.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where in the record do we find this information that has been alluded to about the comparison between the increase in costs under this plan and national inflation figures and national medical fees?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Appendix C in the back of the Respondents' brief.
It is all--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Appendix?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --Yes, it is right at the back of the brief, the very last pages.
You can see there--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What page is it, now?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --Just turn to the back, right inside the back cover.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: And you can see that the rate of increase and the average annual change is less than any of the other numbers there which are there for purposes of comparison, the National Index for Medical Care, the Consumer Price Index for Physician Services, the Metropolitan Phoenix Medical Care Index.

Whether or not the same result could be accomplished in a less restrictive way is something that is in dispute, obviously, listening to Petitioner's argument and Respondents', and that in itself shows that this is not a case that is ripe for summary judgment at this time.
We need to know more.
We need to know enough about the industry in which this happened.
We need to know about what the effects of this are.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I must confess, I am puzzled about why we need to know more.
I can understand your argument that it is not necessarily unlawful.

But can't we assume that you are going to prove that you have kept prices down, or kept the rates down, and that you have done a wonderful job for the people of the city, and there are still the same legal issues there?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Well, the legal issue is whether you are going to characterize that as price fixing, and what I am suggesting to you is that the evidence that is in this record does not enable you to make that characterization.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't see how a showing that the prices are lower than they would have been if they followed the general trend in the economy has any bearing on whether it is price fixing or not.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Because we are talking about different prices for different things.
We are talking about a comparison between what doctors bill patients and what insurers pay for the services that they have agreed to provide to their insureds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I understand all that, but I just don't understand how any of the things you have described are relevant to the legal issue.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: They are relevant because they show that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We have to decide, A, is this a price fixing agreement, and B, if it is, it is obviously maximum rather than minimum, although I know there is an argument to the contrary, but I think you are definitely right on that, and if it is a maximum price fixing agreement, is it unlawful.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --Well, you have to look at it in the same way that the Court analyzed the Broadcast Music agreement.
Are you creating something that is different?
In Broadcast Music--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You are arguing that you are creating something different.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say it is good, because it keeps prices down.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: No, we are saying it is good because it offers a different product than the individual doctors offer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the doctors don't perform different operations under this plan than if there were a free market.
You don't really contend that.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Yes, but they--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You hope they don't, anyway.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --They agree that they will not have the patient at risk for the difference--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They won't charge any more than the schedule.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --between what his insurance i and what the bill is.

It is a very important difference if you happen to be a patient and you don't have that type of insurance coverage, and it is the same sort of thing that you have in Broadcast Music, because you also have the alternative, and there is nothing in the record to contradict that everybody has the alternative of doing it individually, unilaterally, and that the pricing of that transaction is not affected in any way by the operation of this particular entity which is giving you a new type service, a new type of product, and that is the important--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your heavy reliance on Broadcast Music makes me wonder if you are in effect acknowledging that the fact that it is doctors in the medical profession doesn't really have much bearing on the issue.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: --The fact that it is doctors in the medical profession suggests that we have to know more in order to see whether doctors in the medical profession should be treated like people who sell iron pipe or people who sell gasoline.
I suggest that you don't treat them the same because the considerations are different.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or people who sell music.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Excuse me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or people who sell music.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Or people who sell music.
The considerations are different.
The Court has recognized that the considerations can be different.
We have to have a full record to see whether in fact they are different, and until you know that, you can't condemn this, or you shouldn't condemn this.

Furthermore, it would be unfair to have summary judgment granted before the Respondents have had an opportunity to put in the record the evidence that they claim shows pro-competitive aspects and the lack of affect on price of this particular conduct.
We haven't had that opportunity.
I have alluded to the pro-complaint discovery that the Petitioners had.
Because of the way this case came through procedurally, we just haven't had discovery on who is in the market, how they price, whether there is any effect all on their prices.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the most, if I hear you, that you could really insist on is that we ought to have a mini-trial first to see whether the rule of reason applies, or whether it is per se.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: It would be something like what happened in the Society of Professional Engineers case, in which you developed a full record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you wouldn't necessarily have an entire antitrust trial on the assumption that the rule of reason was going to apply.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: It would depend upon whether the judge thought that would be the most expeditious way.
He could have the full trial and then during the course of the trial make that determination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you wouldn't be entitled to it.
Under the argument you are now making, you should have no more than a chance to put whatever evidence in that might be useful in deciding whether this is per se illegal price fixing.

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: Yes, and unless the Petitioner was able to put in undisputed facts to show that it was per se, then they cannot prevail on a per se theory and you do have to have that trial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think that a district judge has discretion in the timing of his decision as to whether to grant or deny a motion for partial summary judgment?

turn.speaker: philip_p_berelson
turn.label: Mr. Philip P. Berelson
turn.text: I think a district judge does, but that the discretion has to take into account the experience and the theory and whether the precedents which deal with per se liability on price fixing are applicable and appropriate in this particular type of marketplace on the particular facts that are set forth.

In this case, the district court, if he has discretion, exercised it wisely, we believe, and we are just asking you to uphold that and to allow the proceedings to go back to their normal course, have discovery, and have a determination after appropriate discovery and after a full record.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
